intro: Acacia aculeiformis, commonly known as the slender thorn acacia, is a shrub or small tree native to arid and semi-arid regions of Africa. It is characterized by its dense, thorny branches and small, bipinnate leaves that are often reduced to spines. The plant produces yellow flowers in compact, globular clusters, which are followed by elongated, flat pods containing seeds. It is well adapted to harsh environments, with deep roots that help it access water from deeper soil layers. Acacia aculeiformis is also valued for its use in traditional medicine and as a source of firewood.

Its family is Fabaceae, commonly known as the legume or bean family, characterized by their distinctive pod fruits and nitrogen-fixing abilities. Its genus is Acacia, a large group of shrubs and trees known for their compound leaves and often spiny thorns. Its species is Acacia aculeiformis, a specific type of acacia known for its aculeate (spiny) structures and is commonly found in arid and semi-arid regions.

Acacia aculeiformis plays an important ecological role in supporting local wildlife and maintaining biodiversity.
